trans-unit.source: UNHOOKING THIS FUNCTION WILL NOT PROPERLY REMOVE THE ADMIN BAR. For that, use show_admin_bar(false) or the ‘show_admin_bar’ filter.

URL for the default image or a default type. Accepts '404' (return a 404 instead of a default image), 'retro' (8bit), 'monsterid' (monster), 'wavatar' (cartoon face), 'indenticon' (the "quilt"), 'mystery', 'mm', or 'mysteryman' (The Oyster Man), 'blank' (transparent GIF), or 'gravatar_default' (the Gravatar logo). Default is the value of the 'avatar_default' option, with a fallback of 'mystery'.
URL if the revision can be restored, false otherwise.
URL is escaped to make it XML-safe.
URL of an image to use for the feed link.
URL scheme to use. See set_url_scheme() for accepted values.
URL to redirect to. Must be absolute, as in "<a href="https://example.com/mypage/">https://example.com/mypage/</a>". Default is to redirect back to the request URI.
URL to the source of the audio file. Default empty.
URL to the source of the video file. Default empty.
UTF-8, tags and entities safe prefix extraction. Entities inside will NOT be counted as one character. For example & will be counted as 4, < as 3, etc.
Undoes any changes to the options since options capture began.
Unfortunately, PHP doesn’t check the certificate against the alternative names, leading things like ‘https://www.github.com/‘ to be invalid. Instead
Unhooks a function or method from a specific filter action.
Unique cache key to be produced when this query is stored in an object cache. Default is 'core'.
Unix timestamp (UTC) for when to next run the event.
Unless $output is empty it will pass through htmlspecialchars before the ‘htmledit_pre’ filter is applied.
Unlike self::getValues(), this returns a string. If there are multiple values, it concatenates them with a comma as per RFC2616.
Unlike the_date() this function will always return the date. Modify output with the ‘get_the_date’ filter.
Unload translations for a text domain.
Unregisters a WP_Widget widget. Useful for un-registering default widgets. Run within a function hooked to the ‘widgets_init’ action.
Unregisters a meta key for posts.
Unregisters a meta key for terms.
Unregisters a meta key from the list of registered keys.
Unregisters a navigation menu location for a theme.
Unregisters the post type meta box if a custom callback was specified.
Unschedules all events attached to the hook with the specified arguments.
Unschedules all events attached to the hook.
Unserialize the JS-instance for storing in the options. It’s important that this filter only get applied to an instance once.
Unserialize value only if it was serialized.
Unset all the children for a given top level element.
Unzips a specified ZIP file to a location on the filesystem via the WordPress Filesystem Abstraction.
Update a comment with values provided in $_POST.
Update a post with new post data.
Update a row in the table
Update a user in the database.
Update an existing post with values provided in $_POST.
Update an option for a particular blog.
Update attachment file path based on attachment ID.
Update cache for thumbnails in the current loop.
Update category structure to old pre 2.3 from new taxonomy structure.
Update comment meta field based on comment ID.
Update link with the specified link categories.
Update log when privacy request is confirmed.
Update meta data by meta ID
Update metadata for the specified object. If no value already exists for the specified object ID and metadata key, the metadata will be added.
Update post meta data by meta ID.
Update term based on arguments provided.
Update the “recently-edited” file for the plugin or theme editor.
Update the ‘archived’ status of a particular blog.
Update the custom_css post for a given theme.
Update the cached policy info when the policy page is updated.
Update the count of sites for the current network.
Update the custom taxonomies’ term counts when a post’s status is changed.
Update the details for a blog. Updates the blogs table for a given blog id.
Update the last_updated field for the current site.
Update the maximum user level for the user.
Update the metadata cache for the specified objects.
Update the network-wide counts for the current network.
Update the post type for the post ID.
Update the status of a user in the database.
Update the value of a network option that was already added.
Update the value of an option that was already added for the current network.
Update the value of an option that was already added.
Update theme modification value for the current theme.
Update this blog’s ‘public’ setting in the global blogs table.
Update user meta field based on user ID.
Update user option with global blog capability.
Updated the $widget parameter to also accept a WP_Widget instance object instead of simply a WP_Widget subclass name.
Updated the $widget parameter to also accept a WP_Widget instance object instead of simply a WP_Widget subclass name.
Updated to always return a WP_Site object.
Updated to use a PHP5 constructor.
Updates Terms to Taxonomy in cache.
Updates a link in the database.
Updates a meta value for an object.
Updates a particular instance of a widget.
Updates a post meta field based on the given post ID.
Updates a session based on its verifier (token hash).
Updates a single term from a taxonomy.
Updates a site in the database.
Updates all bulk edited posts/pages, adding (but not removing) tags and categories. Skips pages when they would be their own parent or child.
Updates an existing Category or creates a new Category.
Updates an existing comment in the database.
Updates database when sending trackback to prevent duplicates.
Updates metadata cache for list of post IDs.
Updates metadata cache for list of site IDs.
Updates metadata cache for list of term IDs.
Updates multiple meta values for an object.
Updates one item from the collection.
Updates or inserts a link using values provided in $_POST.
Updates settings for the settings object.
Updates the ‘user_level’ user metadata (includes prefix that is the database table prefix) with the maximum user level. Gets the value from the all of the capabilities that the user has.
Updates the blog_public option for a given site ID.
Updates the CRON option with the new CRON array.
Updates the IIS web.config file with the current rules if it is writable.
Updates the amount of terms in taxonomy.
Updates the cache for the given term object ID(s).
Updates the comment cache of given comments.
Updates the comment count for post(s).
Updates the comment count for the post.
Updates the count of sites for a network based on a changed site.
Updates the data for the session with the given token.
Updates the database tables to a new schema, but without displaying results.
Updates the database tables to a new schema.
Updates the htaccess file with the current rules if it is writable.
Updates the last-used postmeta on a header image attachment after saving a new header image via the Customizer.
Updates the list of roles, if the role doesn’t already exist.
Updates the network cache of given networks.
Updates the post’s terms from a REST request.
Updates the user’s meta data option with capabilities and roles.
Updates the user’s password with a new encrypted one.
Updates the user’s sessions in the usermeta table.
Updates the values of additional fields added to a data object.

Upgrade WordPress to new version. 4.1. Copy all files/folders other than wp-content 4.2. Copy any language files to WP_LANG_DIR (which may differ from WP_CONTENT_DIR 4.3. Copy any new bundled themes/plugins to their respective locations
Upgrade the revisions author, add the current post as a revision and set the revisions version to 1
Upgrader Skin for Ajax WordPress upgrades.
Upgrader Skin for Automatic WordPress Upgrades
Upgrades the database if needed during a site update.
Upload the file to be cropped in the second step.
Uploads a file, following your settings.

Upstream functions (like get_the_terms() and is_object_in_term()) are responsible for populating the object-term relationship cache. The current function only fetches relationship data that is already in the cache.
Use ‘comment_form_default_fields’ to filter the comment fields.
Use ‘get_terms_args’ to filter the passed arguments.
Use wp_delete_site() internally to delete the site row from the database.
Use wp_schedule_event() to schedule a recurring event.
Use wp_schedule_single_event() to schedule a non-recurring event.
Use RegEx to extract URLs from arbitrary content.
Use a plugin instead. See #41217 for an example.
Use category slug (not name, this or any children).
Use of this filter can result in unpredictable behavior, and is not recommended.
Use term names or slugs for display. Accepts 'name' or 'slug'. Default 'name'.
Use the $prev_value parameter to differentiate between meta fields with the same key and comment ID.
Use the $prev_value parameter to differentiate between meta fields with the same key and site ID.
Use the $prev_value parameter to differentiate between meta fields with the same key and user ID.

Use the $sanitize argument to manually re-sanitize the option before returning errors. This is useful if you have errors or notices you want to show even when the user hasn’t submitted data (i.e. when they first load an options page, or in the ‘admin_notices’ action hook).
Use the “The Tortoise and the Hare” algorithm to detect loops.

Use the get_template() method, not the ‘Template’ header, for finding the template. The ‘Template’ header is only good for what was written in the style.css, while get_template() takes into account where WordPress actually located the theme and whether it is actually valid.
Use the ‘add_user_to_blog’ action to fire an event when users are added to a blog.
Use the ‘deprecated_hook_run’ action to get the backtrace describing where the deprecated hook was called.
Use the ‘remove_user_from_blog’ action to fire an event when users are removed from a blog.
Use the $prev_value parameter to differentiate between meta fields with the same key and post ID.
Use the $prev_value parameter to differentiate between meta fields with the same key and term ID.
Use the global $error to get the reason why the login failed. If the username is blank, no error will be set, so assume blank username on that case.
Use the rest_authentication_errors filter to restrict access to the API
Use this filter to add any data- attributes that are required to be validated as a URL.
Use this filter to add support for custom data types, or to filter the result.
Use this filter to adjust the array of sizes returned by the rest_get_avatar_sizes function.
Use this filter to adjust the url returned by the get_rest_url() function.
Use this function to restore the context of the template tags from a secondary query loop back to the main query loop.
Use this hook to add extra fields to the widget form. The hook is only fired if the value passed to the ‘widget_form_callback’ hook is not false.
Use this only before wpdb::prepare() or esc_sql(). Reversing the order is very bad for security.
Used as a wrapper for PHP’s parse_url() function that handles edgecases in < PHP 5.4.7.
Used as active callback for static front page section and controls.
Used as the ‘sanitize_callback’ for each $sidebars_widgets setting.
Used by 120 functions | Uses 0 functions
Used by 0 functions | Uses 0 functions
Used by get_dirsize() to get a directory’s size when it contains other directories.
Used by 0 functions | Uses 0 functions
Used by wp_set_current_user() for back compat. Might be deprecated in the future.
Used by usort() as a callback, should not be used directly. Can actually be used to sort any term object.
Used during the new site registration process to ensure that each site name is unique.
Used for errors encountered during the initial loading process, before the locale has been properly detected and loaded.
Used for generating SQL clauses that filter a primary query according to metadata keys and values.
Used for generating SQL clauses that filter a primary query according to object taxonomy terms.
Used for querying the database for a value from URL.
Used for sending data that is expected to be in the body.
Used in core to mark a user as spam or "ham" (not spam) in Multisite.
Used in the admin widget config screen.
Used in the comments.php template to list comments for a particular post.
Used internally to generate a SQL string related to the ‘search’ parameter.
Used internally to generate an SQL string for searching across multiple columns
Used internally to generate an SQL string for searching across multiple columns.
Used internally to get a list of comment IDs matching the query vars.
Used internally to get a list of network IDs matching the query vars.
Used internally to get a list of site IDs matching the query vars.

Used on the Edit Post and Add New Post screens. Needed to ensure the page is not loaded from browser cache, so the post title and editor content are the last saved versions. Ideally this script should run first in the head.
Used on user-edit.php and profile.php to manage and process user options, passwords etc.
Used only for custom functionality in JavaScript.
Used primarily to route internal requests through WP_REST_Server.
Used to allow the commenter to see their pending comment.

Used to get the max level based on the capabilities the user has. This is also based on roles, so if the user is assigned the Administrator role then the capability ‘level_10’ will exist and the user will get that value.
Used to make the theme installer work for no-js.

Used to quickly retrieve the path of a template without including the file extension. It will also check the parent theme, if the file exists, with the use of locate_template(). Allows for more generic template location without the use of the other get_*_template() functions.
Used to update the file path of the attachment, which uses post meta name ‘_wp_attached_file’ to store the path of the attachment.
Used when a blog’s tables do not exist. Checks for a missing $wpdb->site table as well.
Used when checking parameters in get_param().
Used when you want to keep structures with translatable plural strings and use them later when the number is known.
Used when you want to use a translatable plural string once the number is known.
Used when you want to use the appropriate form of a string based on whether a number is singular or plural.
Used when you want to use the appropriate form of a string with context based on whether a number is singular or plural.
Used with the attachments post type.

Useful for category template files for displaying the category page title. The prefix does not automatically place a space between the prefix, so if there should be a space, the parameter value will need to have it at the end.
Useful for creating new tables and updating existing tables to a new structure.

Useful for tag template files for displaying the tag page title. The prefix does not automatically place a space between the prefix, so if there should be a space, the parameter value will need to have it at the end.

Useful for taxonomy term template files for displaying the taxonomy term page title. The prefix does not automatically place a space between the prefix, so if there should be a space, the parameter value will need to have it at the end.

Useful for when the template only needs to display the month and year, if either are available. The prefix does not automatically place a space between the prefix, so if there should be a space, the parameter value will need to have it at the end.
User ID for the site administrator. Passed to the wp_initialize_site hook.
User ID. If supplied, the user will be updated.

User data to display. If the selected item is empty then the 'user_login' will be displayed in parentheses. Accepts any user field, or 'display_name_with_login' to show the display name with user_login in parentheses. Default 'display_name'.

User options are just like user metadata except that they have support for global blog options. If the ‘global’ parameter is false, which it is by default it will prepend the WordPress table prefix to the option name.
User-agent value sent. Default 'WordPress/' . get_bloginfo( 'version' ) . '; ' . get_bloginfo( 'url' ).
Username of an author to filter themes.
Username of an plugin author to filter plugins.
Username to query for their favorites.
Users are sent to the admin page if logged-in, or the registration page if enabled and logged-out.
Uses parse_str() and stripslashes if magic_quotes_gpc is on.
Uses wp_rand() is used to create passwords with far less predictability than similar native PHP functions like rand() or mt_rand().
Uses PHP7 random_int() or the random_compat library if available.
Uses a local video if present, or falls back to an external video.

Uses an array of stopwords (terms) that are excluded from the separate term matching when searching for posts. The list of English stopwords is the approximate search engines list, and is translatable.
Uses sprintf to append the amount of zeros based on the $threshold parameter and the size of the number. If the number is large enough, then no zeros will be appended.

Uses the SQL DESC for retrieving the table info for the column. It will help understand the parameters, if you do more research on what column information is returned by the SQL statement. Pass in null to skip checking that criteria.
Uses the WordPress database object to query for the comments. The comments are passed through the ‘comments_array’ filter hook with the list of comments and the post ID respectively.
Uses the global $post to check whether the post requires a password and if the user has the password for the post. If not then it will return before displaying.
Uses the shunting-yard algorithm to convert the string to Reverse Polish Notation tokens.
Uses the transient data from the updates API to determine the known installed plugins.
Uses the transient data from the updates API to determine the slugs of known installed plugins. This might be better elsewhere, perhaps even within get_plugins().

Uses three constants: WP_DEBUG, WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY, and WP_DEBUG_LOG. All three can be defined in wp-config.php. By default, WP_DEBUG and WP_DEBUG_LOG are set to false, and WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY is set to true.
Uses: get_theme_root() to retrieve the absolute path to the themes directory, get_template() to retrieve the directory name of the current theme.
Using ! empty() because strpos() may return non-boolean values that evaluate to false. This would be problematic when using a strict "false === strpos()" comparison.
Using a single key and value:
Using permalinks and index.php is not in the URL.
Using the ‘false’ setting will fail to produce a new image in the upload directory if one of the image dimensions of the uploaded image are equal to the new image size.

Using the two ‘wp_mail_from’ and ‘wp_mail_from_name’ hooks allow from creating a from address like ‘Name email@address.com‘ when both are set. If just ‘wp_mail_from’ is set, then just the email address will be used with no name.
Using this filter allows to override the default logic, effectively short-circuiting the function.
Using this function is the proper way to output all needed components for both TinyMCE and Quicktags. _WP_Editors should not be used directly. See https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/17144.
Usually you should prepare queries using wpdb::prepare(). Sometimes, spot-escaping is required or useful. One example is preparing an array for use in an IN clause.
Usually, it’s easier to query the site first, which then declares its network. In limited situations, we either can or must find the network first.
Utility class to handle operations on an array of objects.
Utility method to retrieve the main instance of the class.
VHOST is deprecated in favor of SUBDOMAIN_INSTALL, which is a bool.
Valid values for the $field parameter include:
Valid values for the recurrence are ‘hourly’, ‘daily’, and ‘twicedaily’. These can be extended using the ‘cron_schedules’ filter in wp_get_schedules().
Validate a URL for safe use in the HTTP API.
Validate a new site signup for an existing user.
Validate a request argument based on details registered to the route.
Validate a user request by comparing the key with the request’s key.
Validate a value based on a schema.
Validate all active plugins, deactivates invalid and returns an array of deactivated ones.
Validate that file is suitable for displaying within a web page.
Validate the plugin requirements for WP version and PHP version.
Validate user capabilities whether the theme supports the setting.
Validate user signup name and email
Validates a URL for use in a redirect.
Validates a file name and path against an allowed set of rules.
Validates attributes against the current block schema, populating defaulted and missing values.
Validates data for a site prior to inserting or updating in the database.
Validates that a UUID is valid.
Validates the given date_query values and triggers errors if something is not valid.
Validates the given session token for authenticity and validity.
Validates whether the user can query private statuses.
Validates whether this comment is allowed to be made.

Validation is skipped for unregistered settings or for values that are already null since they will be skipped anyway. Sanitization is applied to values that pass validation, and values that become null or WP_Error after sanitizing are marked invalid.
Value for the 'class' attribute of the select element. Default 'postform'.
Value for the 'class' attribute of the select element. Default: none. Defaults to the value of $name.
Value for the 'id' attribute of the select element.
Value for the 'id' attribute of the select element. Defaults to the value of $name.
Value for the 'name' attribute of the select element. Default "new{$tax_name}_parent".
Value for the 'name' attribute of the select element. Default 'cat'.
Value for the 'name' attribute of the select element. Default 'page_id'.
Value of the option that should be selected. Default 0.
Value of the response type position attribute. Accepts 1 (bottom), -1 (top), html ID (after), or -html ID (before). Default 1 (bottom).
Value to order tags by. Accepts 'name' or 'count'. Default 'name'. The 'tag_cloud_sort' filter can also affect how tags are sorted.
Value to use for $show_option_non when no users were found. Default -1.
Value to use for the action attribute in <response>. Will be appended with _$id on output. If false, $action will default to the value of $_POST['action']. Default false.
Value to use for the comment's "comment-page" or "cpage" value. If provided, this value overrides any value calculated from $page and $per_page.
Value to use when no category is selected.
Value to use when no page is selected.
Value. Should NOT already be urlencoded.
Values are expected to be encoded appropriately with urlencode() or rawurlencode().
Various security measures may block the REST API from working, or it may have been disabled in general. This is required for the new block editor to work, so we explicitly test for this.
Verifies a dNSName for HTTPS usage, (almost) as per Firefox’s rules:
Verifies an attachment is of a given type.
Verifies if the recovery mode key is correct.
Verifies that an email is valid.
Verifies the Ajax request to prevent processing requests external of the blog.
Verifies the contents of a file against its ED25519 signature.
Verifies the received SSL certificate against its Common Names and subjectAltName fields.
Verifies the validity and uniqueness of user names and user email addresses, and checks email addresses against admin-provided domain whitelists and blacklists.
Verify if the instance contains errors.
Verify that a reference name is valid
Verify that correct nonce was used with time limit.
Verify the certificate against common name and subject alternative names
Version of the HTTP protocol to use. Accepts '1.0' and '1.1'. Default '1.0'.
Violating our coding standards for a good function name.
WARNING: Changing this data may result in your site not receiving security updates. Please exercise extreme caution.
WARNING: This may be removed from a future release.
WP uses the WP_Metadata_Lazyloader class to queue objects for metadata cache priming. The class then detects the relevant get_*_meta() function call, and queries the metadata of all queued objects.
